Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Observing the Epoch of Reionization with the Murchison Widefield Array
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators in this collaborative proposal will analyze low frequency radio data from the Murchison Widefield Array to detect the spatial power spectrum of fluctuations in the 21 cm signal caused by the first generation of stars and collapsed objects, during an era known as the Epoch of Reionization (EoR). Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate students and postdocs, and engagement of under-represented groups toward careers in science. Community outreach will be undertaken at local urban schools and tribal centers.

The observations will have the sensitivity to measure the rise and fall of the EoR power spectrum, placing meaningful constraints on models of reionization and early star formation. These constraints will have impact on the astrophysics community and could influence how JWST observations are interpreted, constrain the optical depth of cosmic microwave background measurements, and aid our understanding of the early universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observation of the Cosmic Dawn—when the first stars and galaxies begin to be born in the early Universe—was identified as one of the top science priorities by the Astronomy decadal survey in 2010.  One way to probe this period in the history of the Universe is by observing the 21cm radio emission from hydrogen created in the Big Bang. By measuring the rise and fall of the redshifted 21 cm power spectrum with time, we can trace the impact of the first stars and galaxies on the intergalactic medium, the early growth of structure, and its influence on subsequent galaxy and star formation.  Though much indirect evidence exists for the presence of intergalactic hydrogen in the early universe, it has not yet been directly detected in the radio.

 

The Murchison Widefield Array (MWA) was the first of the HERA phase-1 instruments to have finished construction and in 2013 began a program of thousands of hours of observations. This project funded a US team to analyze the new data. There were two primary goals:  The first was to place the best-possible limits on the 21cm emission, and the second was to explore and optimize data analysis and better understand the behavior of the instrument in order to generate knowledge and tools that can be applied to future instruments.

 

During the course of the project, the Arizona State University team planned and carried out the MWA observing program, aided in commissioning, expanded on a new instrument simulation tool, and scaled pipelines to work on the large volume of data. Specific Intellectual Merit outcomes include a paper series exploring foreground effects by comparing data to detailed sky and instrumental simulations and a comprehensive comparison between the results of four different pipelines.  This work culminated in the most-sensitive analysis of MWA observations to date.

 

The ASU team was active in outreach activities on the ASU campus and at local elementary schools.  We participated in typically five large open house events each year, several of them student run, each with hundreds to thousands of visitors. During these events our team members ran a large multi-table booth with hands-on exhibits about the construction of the MWA, cosmology, radio emission from our Milky Way galaxy, and human generated radio interference. These efforts at public engagement have since expanded in scope to include other NSF research projects like the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array. The open house events were also effective learning opportunities for students and postdocs on the team to develop communication and teaching skills.
